1111112112.content:
Astrid felt herself gaining a few extra inches. Gaining a few inches height and in some other places too. As first born, she'd be the one trusted to lead the village. Hiccup could be free. She told herself, free to invent and earn that dismissive viking name.

The gem glowed in Astrid's palm, as it strained to comply. Only a final flare of light coming from it before, the light vanished, and it looked a plain, piece of quartz. Looking about the home, she recognised the chief's place... Well, hers now.... hers and Hiccups.

Spotting her little sister snuggling in the furs, the nearby slab of stone covered by Toothless. She spotted her own bed. The stone slab for Stormfly at the foot of her bed, too.

Hiccup turned restlessly, moaning softly in her sleep, as if facing a nightmare. Kissing her forehead she settled, and Astrid went to bed.

The dull gemstone, she tucked beneath the bed. It didn't show any promise, but she didn't want to lose it... just yet.

- - - - -

The night passed quickly, with her waking to the smell of bacon being fried for breakfast. Looking sideways, Hiccup was yawning and stretching, "Morning Sis..." she said brightly, spotting Astrid's gaze.

The sound of Stoick humming a tune to himself downstairs made Astrid happier than she'd ever been. With both her parents dead, even having a father felt like a luxury.

"Breakfast is ready." the voice calling through, as the humming stopped.

She felt selfish, and a little guilty. But as she took in the new female Hiccup, she was still the same person that Astrid remembered. Still happy, inventive and rather petite. As a young viking woman, she wasn't scrawny, or weak... but petite definitely suited her.

Compared to some of the viking women, Astrid knew she wasn't bulky herself, but she towered a head over her sister, rather than vice versa. It was an odd sensation. Both dragons playfully scuffled before racing out the front door to hunt for their own breakfast.

Fed and watered, they headed down to the arena. Hiccup eager to find out more about the dragon they'd discovered and recovered the previous night. After a restful night it should be calmer, and more willing to accept help for it's injuries.

They chatted about how to gain the dragon's confidence, and how to feed it, help it, and learn from it.

They reached the arena... Well, dragon training academy now.

1112.content:
A few years had passed since, the infamous battle of Dragon Island. Hiccup was now highly regarded amongst the tribe, although still considered ..mmm.. eccentric for a viking. He was frequently off exploring, finding new distant islands and documenting exciting new breeds of dragon.

Fishlegs would even accompany him on some adventures. He had a fine artistic eye and a deft hand for capturing detail. Snotlout was still a proud member of Berk's dragon riders. His father Spitelout was less impressed, as Snotlout was always Lieutenant to Hiccup's leader. Hell, some days he was even lower, following Astrid's ideas and plans.

This was less of a problem now, he told himself as Astrid was becoming more womanly. She was developing her own curves, and at the same time having to fight the traditional viking views of a woman's place in the tribe. A snarl crossed his face as he thought back to the looks that she cast in Hiccup's direction when she thought nobody was looking.

Stoick was clear in his desire that Hiccup follow him as the next leader. Encouraging him to work with everybody and molding him to become the next chief. Snotlout ground his teeth as the idea, it just wasn't the viking way. A chief should rule by strength... not by ... well, not by weakness and alliances.

Ruff and Tuff were curiously still the same, just older. Snotlout knew that Ruff was a woman, but her constant battling with Tuff. Well, it just never seemed that important. Besides the twins had no drive for leadership, at times he wondered if they ever had an idea that wasn't designed to antagonise their other half.

An idea started to form in Snotlout's brain, how he could solve both of these problems at the same time. If only Hiccup were as female as Astrid....

A woman couldn't be a chief.... that just didn't make sense.

Besides he rode a Monstrous Nightmare, whereas Hiccup had to make do with an injured dragon. Clearly he was the better viking. It all made sense. It was for the good of the tribe, for the good of the village. Hell, maybe over time Hiccup would come to thank Snotlout for her transformation.

Snotlout was also sure that a skinny and weak as Hiccup was as a male would mean that she'd become a beautiful, delicate flower of a woman.

But how to carry out such a plan....

11122.content:
Snotlout scuttled off to the Berk library, eager to find the way to sideline Hiccup. It galled him, that even the library was there because of Hiccup, as his eyes scanned over the spines of the two dozen books, he thought of abandoning his plan. But it was too good a plan, so he decided to talk to Fishlegs. As a viking he was a good librarian, (a terrible viking insult). Hell, he'd even authored some of those books himself.

After a few false starts he found Fishlegs and Meatlug on the beach on the far side of the island. Meatlug looked to be randomly blasting and eating rocks while his rider took notes. He waved at him, as he circled Hookfang around, looking for somewhere to land.

Snotlout and Fishlegs had never been the best of friends, but Fishlegs had bottomless reserves of goodwill. Snotlout hated that about him, such weakness. But he put a smile on and waved to him as he walked over.

"Working on a new book..." his voice trailed off, as he struggled to find the subject of any interest.

"Yes... I thought you might like this. We're testing the rocks to see what effects they have on Boulder class dragons." he rubbed Meatlug's stubby little ears affectionately.

Snotlout just pretended to listen, adding the occasional grunt and general agreement to keep him talking. Snotlout was happy for the chance to talk about dragons, and Meatlug in particular. After fifteen minutes or so, he almost snapped.

But with a snarl tried to change the subject instead.

"Yeah... yeah... Boulder class are really interesting. But... er... what about Stormfly... I mean what about ... Sharp class dragons."

He hadn't meant to mention Stormfly, but Astrid was a girl he found very interesting. An interest that went entirely unreturned. As a dragon rider he wasn't short of attention.

"I didn't know you were ... oh, Astrid's dragon ... " he gave Snotlout a sly wink.

"Have you tried Chicken... as an alternative to fish... If you want to win her favour, you will need to get on better with Stormfly. But...." he fell silent, and turned his gaze to the sky. It wasn't really a secret, that Astrid craved the eye of Hiccup, even if she were unwilling to admit it most days.

Perhaps the only vikings unaware of the simmering chemistry were Hiccup and Snotlout themselves.

With a sigh, he started talking about the poisonous spines of the Sharp-class dragons.

"Most immobilise their prey, allowing the dragon time to swoop down and capture their prey, or if necessary slow down an enemy and make their escape."

Snotlout grunted, settling on top of a rock in preparation for a long and boring discussion.

"Some spines are even deadly." he added, as if the name Deadly Nadder were unearned.

Fishlegs then started on about how long it took a dragon to replace a thrown spine.

Snotlout's chin slid off his fist as he listened distractedly. With a snort he distracted Fishlegs.

".... you know that Stormfly is a female." he finished saying, looking over to the bored viking, as if explaining a great secret.

"Yes, and Hookfang is male." he bit back his anger. This wasn't working, and it was frustrating. He was just about to insult the heavy viking and leave, when Fishlegs beckoned him closer with a wave of his chunky hand.

"I've not checked recently... but... she might not be female any longer..."

His ears pricked up at this. He didn't really care about dragon sex, but this sounded promising. He'd certainly never looked that closely.

"How would you find out... and why would she not be female any more..." his confusion written on his face.

The look made Fishlegs smile, even if he hid it from Snotlout.

He waved him closer. "Well, a nadder has a gland that can give it's spines the ability to change sex."

Snotlout lifted his head, barely able to contain his excitement, as Fishlegs chattered on about the advantages for breeding cycles and so forth.

"Will this work on other dragons?" Snotlout asked, genuine fascination clear in his voice.

Snotlout had to restrain himself from acting immediately. It was almost a physical pain to hold himself back from immediate action. It was unviking-like, he told himself. But after flying across the island, Hookfang was in need of a good sleep.

He went to bed and had a good sleep. In his dreams there was even a new figure, a new Hiccup, a female Hiccup... a rival with Astrid for the attention of the new chief in waiting.

He woke to a banging on the door.

Yawning and scratching he went to the door. Without opening he knew who it was. Hiccup.

"Time for the Dawn Patrol." Hiccup's happy voice carried through the thick wood.

"Perhaps a couple of spines through his bedroom window." Astrid suggested half-jokingly... but only half.

As he opened the door the chill air finished the job of waking him up.

Hiccup was already mounting up. Toothless eager to be away. The twins were knocking lumps out of one another as their dragon hovered in the air. On the other side of Hiccup were Astrid on Stormfly and Fishlegs and Meatlug. As ever the gronkle was the most stable of the dragons as they hovered around the viking standing in the doorway.

He took a moment to examine the nadder.

Astrid's control was excellent he hated to admit. But from this angle it was very clear which particular spine that Fishlegs had been describing. Spotting it put a smile on his face.

He leapt to Hookfang's back in a couple of bound, and landed ready to fly.

Hiccup was already leading from the front. They flew in a rough V-formation. With Toothless at the apex. Just to the left and slightly behind went Stormfly. She was followed by the twins on Barf and Belch. Forming a line from Toothless's right was only Meatlug. With a gap for his Monstrous Nightmare to fill.

Once in formation, they circled on the thermals rising higher until they dove in formation across the village, heading for the harbour before doing a complete circuit of the island.

Snotlout was scuffing his way along the beach on the far side of the island. It wasn't much of a beach, made more of pebbles, than sand. But at least he could kick the stones as he muttered to himself about life's unfairness.

He cursed Hiccup for being born the chief's son. He cursed Astrid for being Hiccup's favourite. He cursed Fishlegs for his love of books, and the details of dragon behaviour. He cursed the twins and their damned pranks and jokes. He cursed them all for failing to appreciate him, and Hookfang.

Putting a tremendous effort in he sent one stone flying, off his toe and out to sea. He hopped furiously, as the pain hit his brain. A scream aimed at the sky was only heard by the distant Hookfang, sunbathing on a nearby rock. He went to kick another pebble in his fury. Barely restraining himself in time.

After a moment, his eye was drawn to the odd stone. It was unlike the dark sharp edged pebbles, or the rounder, redder ones. It looked really out of place. Not just on the beach, but unlike any stone he'd seen anywhere. It glowed with an inner light, that danced as he looked at it.

Even picking it up, and examining it more closely. The light was more lively than even quartz or any other precious stone, the few he'd seen Trader Johann display. There wasn't much use for precious stones.

Though he hated the idea, Fishlegs sprang to mind. He hated asking him questions, having to listen to the answers. But with him riding that dull Gronkle, he had to admit Fishlegs knew his rocks. Obviously, he wouldn't trust him with a valuation. But he could trust him with a name or a type of rock.

11123111.content:
Snotlout kept a loose grip on the stone in his pocket as he walked. It seemed to radiate heat. Realising it's usefulness, he started scanning the beach as he walked back and forth. At times he'd kick at the stones, in frustration. Night flying and flying higher above the clouds was a chilly business, and any relief would be happily welcomed.

Despite his natural superiority, he knew he wasn't regarded as the smartest of the Dragon riders. With Fishlegs' seemingly endless knowledge more annoying than he wanted to admit. He also distrusted Hiccup's intuition with dragons. After half an hour, on the beach, it was getting darker, and he hadn't found any more of those glowing stones.

Pulling it from his pocket he wondered if it could work as a torch at night. Doubting that thought even as it occurred, the stony beach wasn't exactly speckled with glowing stones.

But as he withdrew it, he spotted something worrying. The damned thing had grown, and was encasing his hand in it's stony embrace. He tried shattering it against boulders on the beach. But beyond sending off a few sparks didn't do any damage. Worryingly, also the stone's glow pulsed in time with Snotlout's heart.

Trying nightmare gel, he tried to burn it away. But it burned brightly without weakening it at all. Before Snotlout's eyes, it's flame flickered and failed much quicker than it should have. The reason became clear with the next few beats of Snotlout's heart, as the stone surged up his arm, binding and locking his wrist in one position. Four heartbeats later, it had locked his elbow into a bent pose.

Afraid of being glued to Hookfang, or stuck to his saddle, it took him a moment to realise his danger. As his pulse raced, it seemed like the rush of speed was spent, as the stone advance slowed as it approached his shoulder.

He confronted his isolation, and called Hookfang over. It looked like the glow was distorting his arm, making it look different. An internal yellow glow, a hint of sparkles seemed to light his flesh from within. Mounting Hookfang from the other side, he was soon airborne and headed back to the village.

No longer the hero, with the magic warming stones. Now, he was the invalid, the fool. He cursed himself for her impetuous bravery in risking this unknown danger.

Hiccup was passing through the village, his mind was wandering and he bumped into the village wise woman. With a crash they both fell to the ground. Apologising profusely he jumped to his feet and helped her up.

He helped Gunna back to her feet. Before he could stop himself he was offering to help her back to her home.

The young viking usually shunned it, with rumours and stories that delighted and scared them as children. Of course, he was too old and worldly for such things. But he still cast a mindful glance backwards, wanting to be sure that at least one person could see where he was going, should she turn him into a snake or some such thing.

She barely talked, and only leaned lightly on the young viking. Hiccup was happy with silence himself, and perked up when Mildew looked to be walking towards him ... probably with another complaint about dragon damage ... When he saw Gunna, he changed his direction and broke eye contact.

"Won't you at least come in for a 'thank you' drink." she offered when they reached her front door.

He felt a bit silly for being so quiet. "Are you sure, you're all right?" he asked intending to turn down the drink. After all, Toothless needed a good flight and his father would have a job for him .... or ..... or Gobber could use his help...

As if sensing his unease, she skewered him with a sharp gaze, making him even more nervous.

"I can answer your questions..... all your questions." before she vanished inside her home. But the door remained open behind her.

Astrid was wandering through Berk, not paying attention to where she was going. She was feeling very frustrated, having just failed to pull off her latest stunt. It had left Stormfly with a badly injured wing, and herself with badly injured sense of dignity.

She'd broken into floods of tears, a rare display for her. But the idea that her pride had caused Stormfly pain just tore at her heart. Until Fishlegs and Hiccup arrived on the scene, she just watched horrified, as her dragon's wings, just flailed, painfully. Hiccup wanted to comfort Astrid, but was himself pulled towards the Deadly Nadder. Fishlegs examined the injured wing, tentatively running his fingers over the membrane, and the bones beneath.

"She'll be fine... But she needs to rest and recover."

Astrid promised her dragon would eat only the finest chicken until she was sky-worthy again. She found herself clamped onto Hiccup's shoulder, as the pain and fear left her body.

Hiccup wanted to be sure that she was okay, but Astrid wanted to be alone. Hiccup was used to Astrid, and kissing her gently on the cheek let her wander away. He called out re-assurances to her as she left. Dearly she wanted to go with Stormfly, but wasn't sure she could handle the rising guilt, or the endless questions from Fishlegs.

Even stomping along the beach angrily was frustrating. The sand just absorbed her angry footsteps, and the advancing waves, just washed her prints away.

The night was falling before she realised how much time had passed. It had given her a lot of time to think. She had come to some very uncomfortable conclusions.

That deep down, that she felt as a woman... somehow unworthy of being with Hiccup. She knew that her place in viking society was not as high as the boys. They were expected to become warriors, to fight for the clan... to fight for the village ... to fight for his partner.

She thought of her only female companion. Ruffnut. Tolerated only for her stupidity, and the fact that she was too similar to her brother. Her entire life had been a battle to be taken seriously. And now.... And now, it had caused Stormfly ... she sobbed, as she considered how much worst it could have been. Her arrogance... her pride... her insecurity...

If only she didn't feel the need to prove herself... everyday ... every time ... if only she'd been born a boy. She could be a friend to Hiccup, an equal...

She was disturbed from her thoughts, by a small cough.

Looking around, then down... she spotted Gunna. Berk's wise woman.

"Feeling a little distracted are we?"

"Feeling a little out of place..."

From behind her back she pulled out a scarlet stone. It glowed with an internal light, sparkling and teasing.

He ran his hand over his chin, once more. Just to confirm.

Yup... he needed a shave. Beneath his breastplate, he discovered he was male. That he was... he guessed Hiccup's brother.

He wasn't sure how he knew that... but it felt right. A fact that couldn't be doubted.

Gunna...

Even her dreams she snorts at the idea of leaving her defence in the hands of Fishlegs and Tuffnut. The idea of her having to settle down, even if it is Hiccup that everybody sees as her natural mate.

She tosses uncomfortably, as she shakes off those thoughts, both enticing and scary.

If she were a dragon, she'd never have to make these kind of compromises. If she could just fly like Stormfly, the world would be perfect. Her dreams faded into incoherence and she dozed deeply, a rasping snore signaling her rest. A snore that no viking ever managed to convince her was real.

With Stormfly keeping her warm, Astrid slept well into the afternoon. But as the Sun shot through the clouds, and the wing that was extended over her head. She gave a yawn and stretched. Sensing the movement, Stormfly uncurled, and was soon tilting her head to one side and then the other.

Both were unaware of how their movements mirrored each other.

Astrid scratched her ride under the chin with a promise of chicken when they reached home. Stormfly gave her an affectionate head-bump like an oversized cat. The best dragon... Astrid said half-aloud, as the ran a hand over her fine crest of head spines.

Astrid tried to guess the time by looking at the Sun. But as she covered her eyes, she spotted a membrane between her fingers. It was a vivid blue with splotches of greeny-yellow.

She'd have to fly fast to get home for dinner, and she appreciated the Nadder's speed. Only just slower than Toothless. It was half an hour of a flight, she had wanted the privacy to practice her new trick.

She stopped.

Since she'd woken she'd not felt any pain, relief welled up. She'd not have to hide her injury, and face the jokes of her friends. Bending to touch her toes, she shifted and stretched, twisting her waist one way then the opposite.

Something was off. She slipped her big comfy boots off. Her feet were cold, and as she ran her hands over them, her skin also felt harder and drier.

The light revealed a worrying colour as well. Her feet had the same hint of splotchy blue colouring, extending to just below her knees.

She slid the boots back on, and jumped into Stormfly's saddle. Seconds later, with a push from her powerful legs, and a languid flap of her wings, Stormfly was airborne.

Astrid had questions, and was worried about the shade of blue. More worried than she liked to consider.

However, there weren't any answers here. She'd need to find help from somewhere.

He was out of breath, having spotted and chased the dragon, on spotting them from the ground. She wanted to confide in him, to share her worries. But... "Sorry, Hiccup. I can't fly a patrol, right now." she said dismounting.

A hiss of pain slipping unwanted from her lips, as she landed.

Hiding her hands, she headed for the front door. Not seeing Hiccup's pained face, as he watched powerless to help. Any thoughts of making her fly.... Hell!, if she didn't want to fly she must be ill.

"Astrid." he asked, ready to offer any help as she reached the door. Her death glare turned the words to ash in his mouth.

"Okay... I'll see you later." he finished weakly walking away.

The toes looked wrong. They needed cutting she thought idly, hell even her legs were starting to look blotchy in the half-light of her hut.

The aches drove her to her bed. She really needed to lie down. Every bone felt sore, every muscle stressed. Carefully peeling off her clothes, she found that same webbing seeming to spread. It was forming at her elbow, joining her fore arm and upper arm with elastic flesh. Her clothes obviously making that growth tight and painful, she tossed her top aside.

Yawning, she stretched, and saw that same membrane stretching between her elbow and torso. All looked the same shade of speckled blue that she associated with Stormfly. Listening carefully, she thought she could hear the familiar leathery flap of her wings circling above her home.

As if she were performing her own protective patrol. She only just made to her bed before collapsing there, and falling into a deep sleep.

12411212.content:
Trader Johann had come to Berk once again. It was hard to miss the enthusiastic exclamations of Bucket whenever Johann showed up. Astrid couldn't help but wonder what sorts of things the trader had brought to Berk this time. While weapons were always a good thing and of extra fine quality when they came from Johann, she already had plenty of them...there had to be something equally as useful as a good weapon.

Astrid strode down the docks to Johann's ship, browsing through the man's wares. Unfortunately, she wasn't seeing anything too interesting or out of the ordinary for Johann, sure there were plenty of interesting things, but none that really fit with what she wanted...Hiccup and Fishlegs would probably be all over the books or the things like ink for writing.
"Ah, Miss Hofferson," Johann called happily and making Astrid jump in surprise, "One of my most loyal customers. Anything catching your fancy or anything that I can interest you in?"

"Hey, Johann," Astrid greeted the trader, "And yeah, you certainly can. I was wondering what you might recommend," noticing the man about to speak she quickly held up a hand and cut him off, "That isn't a weapon...I mean they're always nice, or useful, but I have plenty of them all ready. So knowing what I'm like, what else might you have that I'd be interested in?" Johann seemed to pause in deep thought for a moment before beckoning her toward the hold. He began rummaging through several chests and other various containers before finally letting out a cry of success and returning to her with a small bottle.

"Ordinarily I don't put much stock in items claimed to be of a magical nature, but this is something I received from a very reliable source. I'd trust that it does what it's supposed to. This here, is a potion meant to increase the strength, endurance, and durability of the one who drinks it. I was guaranteed that whoever drinks this would become the most physically powerful man, or woman, alive," Johann declared happily. Astrid only looked at the bottle in suspicion, could he really be serious about all of this? You could definitely trust Johann not to cheat you and rob you blind, but his stories weren't always the most reliable. She had no doubt that the contents of the bottle he was offering were something worth a lot of money, but she wasn't sure she believed that it was a magic potion.

If it were true though, that would definitely be something that she was interested in. Especially now with all of the boys hitting their growth spurts, she was still the strongest and the most capable overall of the group, but they'd been catching up to her and she was afraid that they'd only surpass her as time went on....even Hiccup of all people had finally started to not only grow taller, but also to bulk up slightly, he was still a skinny twig, but he was getting there. This potion would give her the edge she needed to stay at the top if it actually worked. She decided she'd take the gamble and buy the potion. If it didn't work she could always tell Johann and he'd either get her money back or get her an item of roughly equal value. "I'll take it," Astrid declared firmly, digging around in her money sack for the amount that Johann specified.

After climbing out of the hold of the ship she rushed back to her home, she didn't want to drink the potion out in public and attract anyone's attention. She wasn't afraid of questions they'd ask, but she did worry that they might try to take it from her and use it themselves. Once inside the safety of the Hofferson clan's home and making sure that no one else from her family was around, Astrid gently pulled the stopper out of the bottle and downed the whole thing. It didn't taste awful, but it wasn't necessarily an experience she enjoyed either.....Astrid suddenly felt rather woozy and like she was going to faint, she could only assume that it was the potion taking hold....it was that or she'd accidentally poisoned herself. She staggered to her bed and crawled into it before her eyelids began to close and she passed out into a deep sleep.

Once his arms were free, he pried the rest off his body, revealing his legs and torso. His skin felt smoother to his blind touch, perhaps taking off the loose hair and leaving that bound in the cocoon.

Carefully he peeled the last of the white powdery shell from his face, and he was greeted by Meatlug. The dragon gave it's master a friendly lick to see his face again.

15211.content:
The six dragon riders had landed just outside the forest. The trees were too densely packed to fly between them... and with the prize that Fishlegs hoped to find, and Hiccup wanted to meet.

Leaving their dragons on the verge of the forest, they had to search on foot, looking for caves, hollows, and any hiding places they could find in the thick tree cover. The ground was overgrown, forcing them to cut their way through the bracken and heather as they hunted.

Hiccup had thought he'd spotted one on the ground as he flew over the area. A second visit by Astrid on Stormfly only confirmed it.

A Changewing... and if Fishlegs was right, probably injured. The hope being to make contact with and hopefully train a Mystery class dragon. If they had a tame, one they could examine it closely... It's variable coloured scales, giving it a chameleon-like ability to disappear into the background.

The use the riders could make of colour-shifting armour would aid their own attempts at stealth. Their own dragon scale armour was light and strong. Another bond with their mount. But, the potential for near-invisibility was too tempting.

Splitting into three groups, they naturally paired up. Astrid and Hiccup taking one direction, cutting their way through the undergrowth with her axe, and his flaming sword. Fishlegs, and Snotlout were a team, neither wishing to work with either of the Thorston twins. Fishlegs' gronkle iron sword making light work of the plant-life, and Snotlout using brute force to kick and beat his way through.

The twins charged into the green dappled darkness, as an unstoppable force of nature. Bickering and fighting, they didn't seem to notice the hazards as they vanished into the depths of the woods.

- - - - -

It was a long and frustrating search with the riders finding little of interest. The Changewing too well hidden from their random thrashing search. Sadly, lots of biting and stinging insects seemed to find them easily.

Fishlegs found a cave, and traces of the acid green spittle of the dragon burning hollows in the floor. Proof that their definitely was one in the area. Calling out, Hiccup and Astrid joined them in the cave, agreeing that the burns seemed to be recent, and that the dragon seemed to be injured... or at least not flying far.

A quick search confirmed there weren't any eggs in the cave, and they agreed they'd need more people to have a chance of finding the dragon. As Snotlout wanted to boast about his discovery of the cave, the burn, and all his conclusions he looked around for the twins.

- - - - -

It was then that the cries of the twins reached them. The sound not of their usual chaotic action. But with an added tone of terror filling their shouts.

"They've found it..." Astrid and Hiccup said at the same moment, before all four raced from the cave towards the sounds of the shouts. It was hard to tell where they were in the forest, but the shouts were getting closer, as they hacked their way forward.

The group burst free of the forest, into the sunlight, surprising even themselves. Quite near the waiting dragons. Looking around they spotted the twins near Barf and Belch. Blinking for the brightness of the Sun, they were relieved to see they didn't look to be in immediate danger.

Without a reason to return to their search, they headed towards their dragons. But, there was still something about the tone of the arguing twins that was.... well, wrong.

15513211.content:
The Night Fury growled in the small human's face.

Just a few minutes ago, this human had shown himself, positively jubilant at the sight of the downed dragon.

For some reason though, the human had released him.

As the dragon was contemplating why, he felt something in his tail.

Or rather, a lack of something.

The dragon's rage bubbled as he realized that the only reason this human had released him was because he could not fly away, and would be easy prey.

'Well,' the dragon thought darkly, 'you stole my life from me, it's only fitting I take yours.'

With that thought, the Night Fury called upon his magic, and jumped into the human's much smaller body.

Hiccup's body spasmed for a few minutes, before it stood up with a smirk, "Life for life, human. Now, I better learn how to act like the hatchling."

15533.content:
The night was dark and cold. The snow was blowing horizontally through the village, and everybody had retreated to their homes for the night. Even the livestock was safely protected in the barns and outbuildings of Berk.

Hiccup was getting Toothless to blast a rock repeatedly just to heat his home. Stoick had considered keeping everyone in the Great Hall, but it wasn't best suited for all the villagers to sleep there and he was sure the storm would blow itself out... well some time during the night.

Toothless looked mournfully at the door. He enjoyed riding the wild currents of a stormy sky... what dragon didn't enjoy the wind beneath it's wings.

Hiccup felt sympathy for his dragons desires, but really didn't fancy taking him up in this weather. He felt sure that his father was right, and it would be rather hard to hide his absence when they were both in such close proximity.

Besides even with his warmest clothes and riding Toothless, he didn't have the same fire in his belly as a dragon. He curled up in the living room, resting his head against Toothless's flank, he was soon asleep. Hiccup didn't wake when his father covered him with a blanket, although Toothless had a wary eye on him.

Satisfied that his son was warm and protected he went off to bed himself. After all, it had been a tiring day preparing the village for the storm. But the black clouds on the horizon hadn't been hard to read.

The only thought that troubled him was Gobber. His friend had chosen to stay at his forge, rather than shelter at home.

But Gobber was resilient, and he assured himself wise enough to go home if he needed. With a deep yawn, he stretched and headed off to bed.

Outside the wind howled, the clatter of an unsecured shutter punctuation the night. But this was no ordinary storm.

Pink sparkles glittered among the snow, as it crashed through Berk, bringing unforeseen consequences to the village.

Astrid woke early, Stormfly curled around her keeping her warm and cosy like a baby dragon. The first light of day was barely brightening the horizon, but she was eager to be up and about.

Giving her a tickle under the chin. The dragon gave a gurgling chuckle at the attention, she knew what was coming next, and Astrid didn't disappoint. She tossed a whole roast chicken towards Stormfly. Snatching it out of the air, she gave a draconian purr, deeper and more resonant than any cat.

She needed no reason to ride her dragon, but she was always eager to keep her edge, and stop Hiccup getting too cocky. She soon had Stormfly saddled, and it was hard to tell which of them was more eager to get airborne. A gust of chill air billowed into the house, as they went outside. The freshly laden snow blanketing the village, only the warmth of the Gobber's forge showed any green around it's dry ground.

With a powerful leap, her thigh muscles propelled her into the air. Astrid guided her dragon towards the sea stacks. A swift slalom should be enough to shake off the cobwebs. Already the fresh air was tickling her lungs as she gulped down a lungful of the freshest air.

Swooping low over the village, it was clear she was the first one to be up and awake. Stormfly raced down the hill, sweeping between the building only five or so feet off the ground. The sheep cowered, as the pair flew past, a rippling of frosty flakes trailing in their wake.

There was a faint pink hue to the snow, which Astrid put down to the low Sun. The sky was hers and hers alone.

They had the sky to themselves, with Stormfly trailing her claws in the water, Astrid trusted her mount instinctively. Objecting to the occasional splash as an unwary fish found it's end scooped up into Stormfly's maw. Astrid held tight to Stormfly, pulling her legs close around the dragon's neck. She soaked up the warmth, as the wind sped past her. Flat out, there weren't many dragons who could beat Stormfly for speed. However, one of them was Toothless, and so she trained hard to offer him competition... and for the chance of her own victory, their own victory.

Out of the blue, a plasma bolt shot past her shoulder. Hiccup was awake. Glancing back over her shoulder she made out the shape of Hiccup, and clutching tightly to his neck, the rider. She waved a challenge to Hiccup, and swerved towards the stacks. Another plasma blast flew past her shoulder, this time closer than she liked. She felt the heat as it passed. It also stopped her from reaching the stacks.

She was pissed, it was too close. She did an evasive turn, and was heading back into the village. It was no surprise that they were instantly on her tail. Air hissed angrily from her lungs, but if she was going to have an argument, she wanted some privacy. Landing on the beach, Stormfly kicked up sand as she landed.

Toothless landed with grace and poise, a wide smile on his face. Hiccup dismounted, a little less gracefully, and pulled off his helmet.
